headline: Executive Order 9066 and Public Proclamations
title: Public Proclamation No. 3
creator: DeWitt, John L.
description: After Japan attacked Pearl Harbor on December 7th, 1941, the United States entered World War II. There was a concern among some people in the United States that anyone of Japanese descent could be a threat to the security of the nation. This fear, though ultimately unfounded, led President Roosevelt to sign Executive Order 9066. This order authorized the Secretary of War to designate certain areas as military zones. Within a couple of weeks of Executive Order 9066, several public proclamations were released. The first two established six military zones along the West Coast, the third limited the freedoms of particular populations in those zones, and the began the forced evacuation of those deemed a threat to the United States, most notably anyone of Japanese descent.
subject: military; proclamations
source: UG 12, University of Idaho President's Office. Records, University of Idaho Library Special Collections and Archives
rights: Educational use includes non-commercial use of text and images in materials for teaching and research purposes. Digital reproduction permissions assigned by University of Idaho Library. For more information, please contact University of Idaho Library Special Collections and Archives Department at libspec@uidaho.edu.

headline: Japanese Relocation
title: Sign at entrance of camp in Kooskia
description: Public Proclamation No. 4 began the forced evacuation and detention of anyone of Japanese ancestry from the West Coast, a large portion of which were American citizens. Forced to leave their homes, businesses, and the lives they had built, they first travelled to assembly centers before being sent to incarceration camps run by the War Relocation Authority (WRA).
subject: concentration camps; relocation; japanese americans;
source: PG 103, Kooskia Internment Camp. Scrapbook, University of Idaho Library Special Collections and Archives
rights: Educational use includes non-commercial use of text and images in materials for teaching and research purposes. Digital reproduction permissions assigned by University of Idaho Library. For more information, please contact University of Idaho Library Special Collections and Archives Department at libspec@uidaho.edu.

headline: What it Meant for Japanese Students
title: Letter from President Dale to University of California, Berkley's President Sproul
creator: Dale, Harrison C.
description: A portion of those being removed from the West Coast were university students. Several universities in these areas had a large percentage of students with Japanese ancestry. Many of these institutions fought to ensure their students could continue working towards their degrees even after evacuation. The President of the University of California, Berkley, Robert Sproul sent letters to universities further inland asking them to accept these students. Due in part to the influence of Governor Chase A. Clark, who held strong anti-Japanese sentiments, no public universities in Idaho were able to accept these students.
subject: correspondence; university; japanese students; relocation
source: UG 12, University of Idaho Presdient's Office. Records, University of Idaho Library Special Collections and Archives
rights: Educational use includes non-commercial use of text and images in materials for teaching and research purposes. Digital reproduction permissions assigned by University of Idaho Library. For more information, please contact University of Idaho Library Special Collections and Archives Department at libspec@uidaho.edu.

headline: Detention Centers in Idaho
title: Letter from Fumiko Shitamae to George Shitamae [3]
creator: Shitamae, Fumiko
description: Approximately 10,000 people with Japanese ancestry were relocated to Idaho during World War II. The majority of those were held at the WRA camp known as Minidoka  located near Hunt in southern Idaho, while a small portion were also sent to the Kooskia Internment Camp in the north which was run by the Immigration and Nationalization Service. Those living in these camps often lived in cramped barracks with cots and a stove for warmth. In some cases, those living in the camp were able to leave during the day to work on nearby farms or other projects.
subject: correspondence; concentration camps;relocation
source: MG 387, George Shihei Shitamae. Papers, University of Idaho Library Special Collections and Archives
rights: Educational use includes non-commercial use of text and images in materials for teaching and research purposes. Digital reproduction permissions assigned by University of Idaho Library. For more information, please contact University of Idaho Library Special Collections and Archives Department at libspec@uidaho.edu.

headline: Idaho Attitudes Towards Japanese Americans
title: Letter from Representative Don C.D. Moore to President Dale
creator: Moore, Don C.D.
description: Though many supported the actions taken by the U.S. Government to protect the country during a time of war, many opposed the actions being taken against the Japanese-Americans within the country. Some people in Idaho argued against the governor's decision barring access to out of state Japanese-American students wishing to attend Idaho universities, calling into question the constitutionality of such actions. Local clergy and organizations wished to ensure those of Japanese descent in their communities were being protected, and offer housing when possible. Though there was still a strong sense of anti-Japanese sentiment among people of Idaho, there were also those who opposed what was happening and did their best to help.
subject: correspondence; anti-racism
source: UG 12, University of Idaho Presdient's Office. Records, University of Idaho Library Special Collections and Archives
rights: Educational use includes non-commercial use of text and images in materials for teaching and research purposes. Digital reproduction permissions assigned by University of Idaho Library. For more information, please contact University of Idaho Library Special Collections and Archives Department at libspec@uidaho.edu.

headline: The Atomic Bomb
title: Explosion at Nagasaki
description: On August 6, 1945 the U.S. dropped the atomic bomb on Hiroshima in Japan. Three days later they dropped another bomb on Nagasaki. These bombings killed tens of thousands of individuals instantly and left the cities in rubble. The effects of these bombings would ultimately take the lives of hundreds of thousands of people. Though they brought about the surrender of Japan, and the end of the war, these bombings had a a lasting effect on the Japanese people who survived them. With the end of the war, those with Japanese ancestry would soon be released from their incarceration camps stateside. They, like the survivors of the atomic bombings would return to a life forever altered by war.
subject: Atomic bomb; explosions
source: UG 31, William Edgar Borah Outlawry of War Foundation. Records, 1931-1987, University of Idaho Library Special Collections and Archives
rights: Material has passed into Public Domain based on date of creation. Digital reproduction permissions assigned by University of Idaho Library. For more information, please contact University of Idaho Library Special Collections and Archives Department at libspec@uidaho.edu.

headline: Japanese Reconstruction and the University
title: Request made by President Morito
creator: Morito, Tatsuo
description: The destruction caused by the atomic bomb was vast. In 1951, Hiroshima University was starting to rebuild and their president, Tatsuo Morito, reached out to institutions across the globe asking for help. He wished to establish his university as a Peace University, so there would be 'No more Hiroshimas.' Requesting a book for their university library to promote an atmosphere of universal friendship, and a tree for their campus, he hoped to achieve this goal. Morito hoped the trees would turn the red-dust left by the bomb green, symbolizing hope and growth. The University of Idaho responded to Morito's request with a book on silviculture, some seed samples, and $3 to plant a tree on their campus. The University of Idaho was only one of 8 instiutions in the U.S. to send seeds to Hiroshima, and one of 18 in the U.S. to send money.
subject: correspondence; Reconstruction (1939-1951)--Japan
source: MA 2019-39, Hiroshima University. Collection, University of Idaho Library Special Collections and Archives
rights: Educational use includes non-commercial use of text and images in materials for teaching and research purposes. Digital reproduction permissions assigned by University of Idaho Library. For more information, please contact University of Idaho Library Special Collections and Archives Department at libspec@uidaho.edu.

headline: A Gift of Remembrance
title: Roof Tile
description: The small contribution the University of Idaho made to Hiroshima University's reconstruction, was long forgotten. In 2011, however, the Martin Institute on campus received a package from the university. It's contents held copies of the letters exchanged between the two universities in the 1950s, the manga series 'Barefoot Gen' recounting the destruction and reconstruction of Japan after World War II, and five roof tiles. The tiles had been blown off the roofs of building in Hiroshima during the atomic bomb and had been collected from the riverbed. This gift had been sent by a student group commemorating the gifts of those who helped them rebuild after the war on the 65th anniversary of the bombing. Their hope was to promote peace through the education and reminder of destruction of nuclear weapons.
subject: roofing tile; world wars; Atomic bomb; rubble;
source: MA 2019-39, Hiroshima University. Collection, University of Idaho Library Special Collections and Archives
rights: Educational use includes non-commercial use of text and images in materials for teaching and research purposes. Digital reproduction permissions assigned by University of Idaho Library. For more information, please contact University of Idaho Library Special Collections and Archives Department at libspec@uidaho.edu.

headline: The Continuous Journey
title: Borah Foundation Peace Walk: Weeping White Mulberry
description: The receipt of these gifts from Hiroshima University prompted the creation of this exhibit to share the mostly forgotten story of how the University of Idaho sent a small gift to Hiroshima University during its reconstruction. In researching the exhibit the creator could not ignore what she found regarding the treatment of those of Japanese descent by Idaho and the University during World War II, thus this collection also discusses the Japanese relocation and the university's stance on accepting Japanese students during the war. The University of Idaho holds a long commitment to overcoming the obstacles to world peace, particularly through the work of The Borah Foundation & Symposium. And like Hiroshima University, the Foundation has planted trees in their efforts, creating the Borah International Peace Grove. The journey to peace is long, many of us remain on the continuous path towards it, and it is our hope that by remembering the struggles and failures of our past we may come together again at the end.
subject: peace; trees
rights: Educational use includes non-commercial use of text and images in materials for teaching and research purposes. Digital reproduction permissions assigned by University of Idaho Library. For more information, please contact University of Idaho Library Special Collections and Archives Department at libspec@uidaho.edu.
